To cultivate effective analog circuit design skills, a foundational grasp of noise sources and their analysis is essential. Additionally, studying noise analysis aids in comprehending the fundamental principles of random signals, which is crucial for understanding oversampling converters. This chapter aims to introduce the basics of noise analysis, followed by an overview of electronic noise sources, circuit analysis, and ultimately, linearity.

It is important to note that this chapter focuses on inherent noise rather than interference noise. Interference noise arises from undesirable interactions between the circuit and its external environment or between different sections of the circuit itself. This noise may or may not manifest as random signals. Examples include power supply noise on ground wires (like a $60-\mathrm{Hz}$ hum) or electromagnetic interference between wires. Interference noise can be substantially mitigated through meticulous circuit wiring or layout. Conversely, inherent noise pertains to random noise signals that can be diminished but never entirely eradicated, as it stems from the fundamental characteristics of the circuits. Examples of inherent noise include thermal, shot, and flicker noise. Inherent noise is only moderately influenced by circuit wiring or layout, such as altering the base resistance of a transistor using multiple base contacts. However, it can be significantly reduced through appropriate circuit design strategies, such as modifying the circuit structure or increasing power consumption.

The chapter is structured as follows: Initially, a time-domain analysis of noise signals (or other random signals) is provided, covering fundamental concepts like rms value, signal-to-noise ratio, and noise summation. Subsequently, a frequency-domain analysis of noise is discussed. Similar to deterministic signals, frequency-domain analysis offers more robust analytical tools compared to time-domain analysis alone. Next, noise models for various circuit elements are presented, followed by noise analyses of actual circuits to offer practical experience. Lastly, while noise sets a lower boundary on the signal amplitude range that a circuit can effectively process, linearity often defines the upper limit. The disparity between these limits defines a circuit's dynamic range. The chapter concludes with explorations of linearity and dynamic range.

While periodic signals like sinusoids exhibit power at specific frequency points, random signals distribute their power across the entire frequency spectrum. For instance, if the time-domain signal depicted in Fig. 9.1 is analyzed using a spectrum analyzer, the resultant spectrum might resemble that shown in Fig. 9.3(a). Note that the horizontal axis represents the standard frequency scale, whereas the vertical axis is measured in microvolts-squared per hertz. This vertical axis quantifies the normalized noise power (mean-squared value) over a 1-Hz bandwidth at each frequency point. For example, the reading at 100 Hz in Fig. 9.3(a) signifies that the normalized power between 99.5 Hz and 100.5 Hz is $10(\mu \mathrm{~V})^{2}$.

Consequently, we define the noise spectral density, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}(\mathrm{f})$, or for current, $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}(\mathrm{f})$, as the average normalized noise power within a 1-Hz bandwidth. The units for $V_{n}^{2}(\mathrm{f})$ are volts-squared per hertz, and for $I_{n}^{2}(f)$, they are amps-squared per hertz. Additionally, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}(\mathrm{f})$ is a positive real-valued function.

Key Point: The frequency-domain representation of a noise signal is its spectral density: the average normalized power measurable within a 1-Hz bandwidth.

It is crucial to highlight that the mean-squared value of a random noise signal at any single precise frequency is zero. In other words, the mean-squared value of the signal in Fig. 9.3(a) at 100 Hz is directly proportional to the bandwidth of the bandpass filter used for measurement. In a laboratory spectrum analyzer, the bandpass filter's bandwidth is controlled by the resolution-bandwidth setting. Thus, as the resolution bandwidth approaches zero, the mean-squared value also approaches zero. Conversely, as the resolution bandwidth increases, the measured mean-squared value rises. Regardless, the measured mean-squared value should be normalized to what would be obtained for a 1-Hz bandwidth when expressing the noise spectral density in units of $\mathrm{V}^{2} /(\mathrm{Hz})$. For instance, if the signal corresponding to Fig. 9.3(a) is measured around 0.1 Hz with a 1 mHz resolution bandwidth, the mean-squared value would be $1(\mu \mathrm{~V})^{2}$, which, when scaled to a 1-Hz bandwidth, equals $1,000\left(\mu \mathrm{~V}^{2}\right) / \mathrm{Hz}$.

An intuitive explanation of measuring a random noise signal with a spectrum analyzer is as follows. A random noise signal continuously varies its frequency across a wide range. A spectrum analyzer, however, is sensitive only to a narrow frequency range defined by its filter's passband, measuring the mean-squared value within this range. The spectrum analyzer's filter responds with a time constant approximately given by

$$
\begin{equation*}
\tau \approx \frac{1}{\pi \mathrm{~W}} \tag{9.18}
\end{equation*}
$$

where W is the filter's bandwidth. Occasionally, the random signal matches the frequency of the spectrum analyzer's filter. Fig. 9.3 Example of voltage spectral density (frequency domain), for (a) spectral density, and (b) root spectral density.

Since spectral density measures the mean-squared value over a 1-Hz bandwidth, the total mean-squared value can be obtained by integrating the spectral density across the entire frequency spectrum. Thus, the rms value of a noise signal can also be derived in the frequency domain using the relationship:

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{n(r m s)}^{2}=\int_{0}^{\infty} V_{n}^{2}(f) d f \tag{9.19}
\end{equation*}
$$

Key Point: The mean square value of a noise signal is the integral of its spectral density over all frequencies.
Similarly, for current noise,

$$
\begin{equation*}
I_{n(r m s)}^{2}=\int_{0}^{\infty} I_{n}^{2}(f) d f \tag{9.20}
\end{equation*}
$$

More generally, the rms noise within a specific frequency range is obtained by integrating the noise spectral density over that range. For example, the rms voltage noise over the range $f_{1}<f<f_{2}$ is

$$
\begin{equation*}
\int_{f_{1}}^{f_{1}} V_{n}^{2}(f) d f \tag{9.21}
\end{equation*}
$$

Finally, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}(\mathrm{f})$ is rigorously defined as the Fourier transform of the autocorrelation function of the time-domain signal, $\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{n}}(\mathrm{t})$. This relationship is known as the Wiener-Khinchin theorem. This definition yields a one-sided spectral density function since the noise is integrated only over positive frequencies, mainly for historical reasons. A two-sided definition would divide the spectral density by two, as the spectral density is the same for positive and negative frequencies for real-valued signals, ensuring the total mean-squared value remains unchanged when integrated over both positive and negative frequencies.

#### EXAMPLE 9.3

What mean-squared value would be measured for the signal in Fig. 9.3 at 100 Hz using a 30 Hz resolution bandwidth on a spectrum analyzer? Also, determine the value for a 0.1 Hz resolution bandwidth.

#### Solution

Since the spectral density function is flat around 100 Hz, the measured value should be directly proportional to the bandwidth. Given the noise spectral density is $10(\mu \mathrm{~V})^{2} / \mathrm{Hz}$ at 100 Hz, the output for a 30 Hz filter is $30 \mathrm{~Hz} \times 10(\mu \mathrm{~V})^{2} / \mathrm{Hz} = 300(\mu \mathrm{~V})^{2}$ (or an rms value of $\sqrt{300} \mu \mathrm{~V}$).

For a 0.1 Hz bandwidth, the measured value would be ten times less than for a 1 Hz bandwidth, resulting in $1(\mu \mathrm{~V})^{2}$ (or an rms value of $1 \mu \mathrm{~V}$).

A prevalent form of noise is white noise. A noise signal qualifies as white when its spectral density remains uniform across a specified frequency range. Put simply, a white noise signal exhibits a flat spectral density, as illustrated in Fig. 9.4, where $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{n}}(\mathrm{f})$ is expressed by

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{n}(f)=V_{n w} \tag{9.22}
\end{equation*}
$$

Key Point: White noise maintains a constant spectral density across all frequencies.
Here, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}$ represents a constant value.
Inserting (9.22) into (9.19) implies that white noise possesses infinite power. Nonetheless, this is not a practical concern because a finite capacitance always exists to limit the noise bandwidth, ensuring the integral in (9.19) converges.

A prevalent noise type is the $1 / f$, or flicker, noise. ${ }^{3}$ The spectral density, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}(\mathrm{f})$, of $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise is approximated by

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{n}^{2}(f)=\frac{k_{v}^{2}}{f} \tag{9.23}
\end{equation*}
$$

where $k_{v}$ is a constant. Thus, the spectral density inversely correlates with frequency, leading to the term " $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise." Regarding root spectral density, $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise is expressed as

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{n}(f)=\frac{k_{v}}{\sqrt{f}} \tag{9.24}
\end{equation*}
$$

Key Point: Flicker noise, or 1/f-noise, exhibits a spectral density proportional to 1/f. Consequently, it decreases at -10 dB/decade.

Note that it is inversely proportional to $\sqrt{f}$ (instead of f). Figure 9.5 exemplifies a signal containing both $1 / \mathrm{f}$ and white noise. Observe that the $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise declines at a rate of $-10 \mathrm{~dB} /$ decade due to its inverse proportionality to $\sqrt{\mathrm{f}}$. The intersection of the $1 / \mathrm{f}$ and white noise curves is termed the $1 /$ f noise corner (occurring at 10 Hz in Fig. 9.5).

Inserting (9.23) into (9.21) yields the power of a $1 / f$ noise source over a finite frequency range $f_{1}<f<f_{2}$.

$$
\begin{equation*}
\int_{f_{1}}^{f_{1}} \frac{k_{v}^{2}}{f} d f=k_{v}^{2} \ln \left(\frac{f_{2}}{f_{1}}\right) \tag{9.25}
\end{equation*}
$$

Thus, the noise power in each decade frequency range equals $\mathrm{k}_{v}^{2} \ln (10) \cong 2.3 \mathrm{k}_{v}^{2}$. Integrating $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise down to dc results in infinite power, but practical scenarios yield finite, reasonable values even with a very low lower integration limit.

#### EXAMPLE 9.4

Determine the rms noise voltage of a $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise source with $\mathrm{k}_{v}^{2}=\left(50 \mathrm{nV}{ }^{2}\right)$ over the frequency range 1 Hz to 100 MHz. What is its rms noise voltage if the lower limit is reduced to 10 nHz?

The range 1 Hz to 100 MHz spans 8 decades. Therefore, the rms noise voltage over this range is $\sqrt{8 \cdot 2.3 \cdot \mathrm{k}_{v}^{2}}=0.215 \mu \mathrm{~V}$. Reducing the lower frequency limit to 10 nHz raises the rms noise voltage to $\sqrt{16 \cdot 2.3 \cdot \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{v}}^{2}}=0.303 \mu \mathrm{~V}$. Circuit noise at frequencies around 10 nHz would only be detectable after a circuit operates continuously for over a year. In such long durations, temperature and aging effects cause device performance shifts indistinguishable from the 1/f noise.

The range from 1 Hz to 100 MHz spans 8 decades. Therefore, the rms noise voltage over this range is $\sqrt{8 \cdot 2.3 \cdot \mathrm{k}_{v}^{2}}=0.215 \mu \mathrm{~V}$. Lowering the lower frequency limit to 10 nHz increases the rms noise voltage to $\sqrt{16 \cdot 2.3 \cdot \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{v}}^{2}}=0.303 \mu \mathrm{~V}$. \end{equation*}

$$

\end{equation*}

We have just observed that the spectral density function is defined by the noise power within each 1-Hz bandwidth. Therefore, theoretically, one could measure the spectral density function by filtering a noise signal with a brick-wall bandpass filter that has a 1-Hz bandwidth. The term "brick wall" here indicates that the 1-Hz bandwidth of the filter is transmitted with a gain of one, while all other frequencies are completely eliminated. However, practical filters can only approximate a brick-wall response as their complexity (i.e., filter order) increases. Consequently, for lower-order filters with a 1-Hz passband, more noise power is transmitted than what is strictly within a 1-Hz bandwidth. To address the fact that practical filters have more gradual stopband characteristics, the concept of noise bandwidth is introduced. The noise bandwidth of a given filter is equivalent to the frequency span of a brick-wall filter that produces the same rms output noise as the given filter when white noise is applied to both, assuming the same peak gain for both filters.

Key Point: The noise bandwidth of a specific filter corresponds to the frequency range of a brick-wall filter that yields the same rms output noise as the specific filter when white noise is applied to both, given the same peak gain.

In essence, for a filter with peak gain $\mathrm{A}_{0}$, the noise bandwidth is the width of a rectangular filter that has the same area and peak gain, $\mathrm{A}_{0}$, as the original filter.

For instance, consider a first-order, low-pass response with a 3-dB bandwidth of $\mathrm{f}_{0}$, as depicted in Fig. 9.9(a). Such a response would result from the RC filter shown in Fig. $9.8(b)$ with $f_{0}=(1 / 2 \pi R C)$. The transfer function $A(s)$ is given by

$$
\begin{equation*}
A(s)=\frac{1}{1+\frac{s}{2 \pi f_{0}}} \tag{9.33}
\end{equation*}
$$

This yields the magnitude response of $A(s)$ as

$$
\begin{equation*}
|\mathrm{A}(\mathrm{j} 2 \pi \mathrm{f})|=\left(\frac{1}{1+\left(\frac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{f}_{0}}\right)^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2} \tag{9.34}
\end{equation*}
$$

An input signal, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{ni}}(\mathrm{f})$, is a white noise source defined by

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{n i}(f)=V_{n w} \tag{9.35}
\end{equation*}
$$

where $V_{n w}$ is a constant. The total output noise rms value, $V_{n o}(f)$, is

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{\mathrm{no}(\mathrm{rms})}^{2}=\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}^{2}}{1+\left(\frac{f}{f_{0}}\right)^{2}} \mathrm{df}=\left.\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}^{2} \mathrm{f}_{0} \arctan \left(\frac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{f}_{0}}\right)\right|_{0} ^{\infty}=\frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}^{2} \pi f_{0}}{2} \tag{9.36}
\end{equation*}
$$

If this same input signal, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{ni}}(\mathrm{f})$, is applied to the filter in Fig. $9.9(b)$, the total output noise rms value becomes

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{\text {brick(rms) }}^{2}=\int_{0}^{f_{x}} V_{n w}^{2} d f=V_{n w}^{2} f_{x} \tag{9.37}
\end{equation*}
$$

By equating the two output noise rms values, $\mathrm{V}_{\text {no(rms) }}=\mathrm{V}_{\text {brick(rms) }}$, we get

$$
\begin{equation*}
\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{\pi \mathrm{f}_{0}}{2} \tag{9.38}
\end{equation*}
$$

Thus, the noise bandwidth of a first-order, low-pass filter with a 3-dB bandwidth of $f_{0}$ is $\pi\left(f_{0} / 2\right)$. Note that, in the common case where a first-order circuit is realized by a capacitor, C, and the resistance seen by that capacitor, $\mathrm{R}_{\text {eq }}$, then

$$
\begin{equation*}
\mathrm{f}_{0}=\frac{1}{2 \pi \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{eq}} \mathrm{C}} \tag{9.39}
\end{equation*}
$$

and the noise bandwidth is

$$
\begin{equation*}
f_{x}=\frac{1}{4 R_{e q} C} \tag{9.40}
\end{equation*}

$$

This results in the magnitude response of $A(s)$ being

$$

An input signal, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{ni}}(\mathrm{f})$, is a white noise source expressed as

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{n i}(f)=V_{n w} \tag{9.35}
\end{equation*}
$$

where $V_{n w}$ is a constant. The total output noise rms value, $V_{n o}(f)$, is

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{\mathrm{no}(\mathrm{rms})}^{2}=\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}^{2}}{1+\left(\frac{f}{f_{0}}\right)^{2}} \mathrm{df}=\left.\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}^{2} \mathrm{f}_{0} \arctan \left(\frac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{f}_{0}}\right)\right|_{0} ^{\infty}=\frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{nw}}^{2} \pi f_{0}}{2} \tag{9.36}
\end{equation*}
$$

If this same input signal, $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{ni}}(\mathrm{f})$, is applied to the filter in Fig. $9.9(b)$, the total output noise rms value becomes

$$
\begin{equation*}
V_{\text {brick(rms) }}^{2}=\int_{0}^{f_{x}} V_{n w}^{2} d f=V_{n w}^{2} f_{x} \tag{9.37}
\end{equation*}
$$

$$
\begin{equation*}
\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{\pi \mathrm{f}_{0}}{2} \tag{9.38}
\end{equation*}
$$

We recently observed that the spectral density function is defined by the noise power within each 1-Hz bandwidth. Consequently, theoretically, one could measure the spectral density function by employing a brick-wall bandpass filter with a 1-Hz bandwidth to filter a noise signal. The term "brick wall" here signifies that the filter passes a 1-Hz bandwidth with a gain of one, while all other frequencies are completely rejected. However, practical filters can only approximate a brick-wall response as their complexity (i.e., filter order) increases. Therefore, for lower-order filters with a 1-Hz passband, more noise power is transmitted than what is strictly within a 1-Hz bandwidth. To address the fact that practical filters exhibit more gradual stopband characteristics, the concept of noise bandwidth is introduced. The noise bandwidth of a specific filter is equivalent to the frequency span of a brick-wall filter that produces the same rms output noise as the given filter when white noise is applied to both, assuming identical peak gain for both filters.

Key Point: The noise bandwidth of a particular filter matches the frequency range of a brick-wall filter that yields the same rms output noise as the given filter when white noise is applied, given the same peak gain for both filters.

One common approximation involves estimating total noise by integrating over frequency, assuming piecewise-linear Bode diagrams are accurate. This simplifies integration formulas, as one only needs to integrate under linear functions and sum the results. The following example illustrates this method.

There are three primary noise mechanisms: thermal, shot, and flicker. In this section, we explore noise models for commonly used circuit elements where all three mechanisms are present. However, we first provide a brief overview of these noise phenomena.

Thermal noise arises from the thermal agitation of charge carriers in a conductor. This type of noise exhibits a white spectral density and is directly proportional to absolute temperature. It is independent of bias conditions (dc bias current) and manifests in all resistors (including semiconductors) at temperatures above absolute zero. Consequently, thermal noise imposes fundamental constraints on the dynamic range attainable in electronic circuits. Notably, thermal noise is also known as Johnson or Nyquist noise, named after J. B. Johnson [Johnson, 1928], who first observed it, and H. Nyquist [Nyquist, 1928], who analyzed it using the second law of thermodynamics.

Shot noise was initially investigated by W. Schottky using vacuum-tube diodes [Schottky, 1918], but it also occurs in pn junctions. This noise results from the discontinuous and pulsatile nature of the dc bias current, which is due to the flow of individual charge carriers. Therefore, shot noise is dependent on the dc bias current and can be modeled as a white noise source. Typically, shot noise is more prominent than thermal noise and is sometimes utilized in the creation of white noise generators.

Flicker noise is the least comprehended among the three noise types. It is present in all active devices and carbon resistors, ${ }^{4}$ but only when a dc current is flowing. Flicker noise generally originates from traps in the semiconductor, where carriers that would typically contribute to the dc current are temporarily held and then released. Flicker noise is also known as $1 / \mathrm{f}$ noise because it is effectively modeled with a $1 / \mathrm{f}^{\alpha}$ spectral density, where $\alpha$ ranges from 0.8 to 1.3. While both bipolar and MOSFET transistors exhibit flicker noise, it is a particularly significant noise source in MOS transistors, whereas it can often be disregarded in bipolar transistors.

In numerous instances, it is necessary to acquire a sampled value of an analog voltage. For instance, switched-capacitor circuits extensively utilize sampling, and sample-and-hold circuits are frequently employed in analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog conversions.

Key Point: When sampling an analog voltage on a capacitor, both the signal component and noise with a mean-square value of $\mathrm{kT} / \mathrm{C}$ are captured, assuming a purely passive sampling network.

Examine a fundamental sample-and-hold circuit, illustrated in Fig. 9.14. As $\phi_{\mathrm{clk}}$ decreases, the transistor deactivates, and in an ideal, noise-free scenario, the input voltage signal at that moment would be retained on capacitance C. Nevertheless, in the presence of thermal noise, the resistance during transistor activation induces voltage noise on the capacitor, with an rms value of $\sqrt{\mathrm{kT} / C}$. Consequently, when the switch is deactivated, both the noise and the desired signal are stored on C. This leads to a fundamental noise limit for sampled signals using a capacitance Can rms noise voltage of $\sqrt{\mathrm{kT} / \mathrm{C}}$. The sampled noise can exceed this limit if the sample-and-hold circuit incorporates active components, such as an operational amplifier.

The sampled noise voltage is unaffected by the sampling rate and remains independent from one sample to another. This observation proposes a method to diminish the noise level in signal measurements. Specifically, when $\mathrm{v}_{\text {in }}$ is a dc (or low-frequency) signal, obtaining a single sample results in a noise voltage of $\sqrt{\mathrm{kT}} / \mathrm{C}$. However, if multiple samples are acquired (e.g., 1,000) and all are averaged, the resulting average will exhibit a lower noise level. The effectiveness of this technique in enhancing measurement accuracy lies in the fact that while individual sampled signal values sum linearly, their noise values (being uncorrelated) combine as the square root of the sum of their squares. This approach is termed oversampling and will be extensively covered in relation to oversampling converters in Chapter 18.
